content: The "Financial Institutions Examination Fairness and Reform Act" is cited as the short title. An amendment to the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council Act of 1978 introduces timeliness requirements for examination reports. The "Financial Institutions Examination Fairness and Reform Act" introduces timeliness requirements for examination reports. Federal financial institutions regulatory agencies must provide a final examination report to a financial institution within 60 days of the exit interview or the provision of additional information by the institution. If a financial institution is not under a resident examiner program, the exit interview must occur within 9 months of the examination's commencement, with the possibility of extension by written notice from the regulatory agency. The Director must provide specific reasons for requesting an extension to complete the examination. Financial institutions can request an appendix with all examination information relied upon by the agency in the final report. SEC. 3. INDEPENDENT EXAMINATION REVIEW DIRECTOR. The Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council Act of 1978 is amended to include the creation of the Office of Independent Examination Review. The Office of Independent Examination Review is established within the Council, with the Independent Examination Review Director appointed to head the office. The Director can hire staff and investigate complaints from financial institutions regarding examinations. Meetings are held regularly to encourage participation. The Office of Independent Examination Review within the Council conducts examination quality assurance for federal financial institutions, reviews examination procedures, and adjudicates supervisory appeals. The Office of Independent Examination Review within the Council conducts examination quality assurance for federal financial institutions, reviews procedures, adjudicates supervisory appeals, and reports annually to relevant committees on examination reviews and recommendations for improvements. The Director is required to maintain confidentiality of information provided by financial institutions. The Director of the Office of Independent Examination Review oversees examination quality assurance for federal financial institutions, reviews procedures, adjudicates supervisory appeals, and reports annually to relevant committees. The term 'Director' refers to the Independent Examination Review Director established under section 1013(a) and (b). SEC. 4. RIGHT TO INDEPENDENT REVIEW OF MATERIAL SUPERVISORY DETERMINATIONS. The Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council Act of 1978 is further amended to include the right to independent review of material supervisory determinations. Financial institutions have the right to obtain an independent review of material supervisory determinations in final examination reports. They must file a written notice with the Director within 60 days of receiving the report, identifying the determination in question and providing reasons for disagreement. The financial institution has the right to request any information relied upon by the agency in the final report that is not in their possession. The Director will determine the merits of the appeal on the record or refer it to an administrative law judge for a hearing within 60 days of receiving the petition for review. The Director will independently review the agency's decision based on relevant statutes, regulations, and evidence presented at the hearing. The final decision by the Director on an independent review shall be issued after the petition for review is received. The Director will conduct an independent review of the agency's decision, which must be finalized within 60 days. The financial institution has the right to seek judicial review of the Director's decision in the United States Court of Appeals. The Director is required to report annually to the relevant congressional committees on actions taken. The Director conducts an independent review of agency decisions within 60 days. Financial institutions have the right to seek judicial review. The Director reports annually to Congress on actions taken. Federal financial institutions regulatory agencies are prohibited from retaliating against institutions or delaying actions based on pending appeals. SEC. 5. ADDITIONAL AMENDMENTS. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Regulator Appeals Process, Ombudsman, and Alternative Dispute Resolution under the Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994. It includes changes to subsections (a) and (b) of Section 309, such as adding the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection as a relevant agency and restructuring paragraphs for clarity. In subsection (e)(2), retaliation includes delaying or withholding approval of requests, notices, or applications that would have been approved if not for the institution's or credit union's rights under this section. In subsection (e)(2), retaliation includes delaying or withholding approval of requests, notices, or applications that would have been approved if not for the institution's or credit union's rights under this section. Amendments are made to ensure appropriate safeguards exist for protecting the insured depository institution or insured credit union from retaliation by any agency referred to in subsection (a) for exercising its rights under this subsection. The text chunk discusses the criteria for issues requiring attention by an institution's management or board of directors, including suspension or removal of expedited processing status due to supervisory or compliance concerns. The text chunk addresses the criteria for issues needing attention in an examination report, without involving criminal law violations. It also clarifies that this subsection does not impact the authority of federal banking agencies to take enforcement actions. Additionally, amendments are made to the Federal Credit Union Act and the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council Act. The Federal Credit Union Act is amended to include the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection as part of the Federal financial institutions regulatory agencies. Additionally, the percentage in section 1005 is changed from "One-fifth" to "One-fourth".
